title: How to Make Root Beer Fudge

steps.headline: Gather all of your ingredients and items necessary for making the fudge and serving it.
steps.description: To ensure that your fudge will harden after being made, prepare space in your fridge to allow the fudge to have a place to cool off after melting. Depending on how much fudge you want to make, the pan shouldn't take up too much space.

steps.headline: Using your saucepan, melt your butter or margarine in it on low heat and stir it until it has melted completely.
steps.description: It should be the consistency of maple syrup or thicker. Add the rest of your ingredients to the saucepan, turn up the temperature and wait until the mixture reaches a boil. Stir constantly.

steps.headline: Clip a small candy or weather thermometer to the side of the saucepan and keep stirring the mixture.
steps.description: Wait until the temperature reaches the 'softball stage', which is 234 degrees F, which should take around 20 minutes or fewer.

steps.headline: Remove the mixture from the saucepan at this point and put it into a bowl.
steps.description: Taking an egg beater or spoon, beat the mixture until it becomes thick as a result of it cooling down significantly.

steps.headline: Immediately after, transfer the mixture into the pan that you made space for in your fridge.
steps.description: Sprinkle it with your chosen toppings, like pecans, peanuts, or even sprinkles! The possibilities are endless for this treat.

steps.headline: Place the pan containing the fudge into the fridge and check it every once in a while to ensure that it is cooling off.
steps.description: After it has cooled enough for you to be able to touch it without feeling heat or getting burnt, slice the fudge into small pieces for serving.

text: Gather all of your ingredients and items necessary for making the fudge and serving it. To ensure that your fudge will harden after being made, prepare space in your fridge to allow the fudge to have a place to cool off after melting. Depending on how much fudge you want to make, the pan shouldn't take up too much space. Using your saucepan, melt your butter or margarine in it on low heat and stir it until it has melted completely. It should be the consistency of maple syrup or thicker. Add the rest of your ingredients to the saucepan, turn up the temperature and wait until the mixture reaches a boil. Stir constantly. Clip a small candy or weather thermometer to the side of the saucepan and keep stirring the mixture. Wait until the temperature reaches the 'softball stage', which is 234 degrees F, which should take around 20 minutes or fewer. Remove the mixture from the saucepan at this point and put it into a bowl. Taking an egg beater or spoon, beat the mixture until it becomes thick as a result of it cooling down significantly. Immediately after, transfer the mixture into the pan that you made space for in your fridge. Sprinkle it with your chosen toppings, like pecans, peanuts, or even sprinkles! The possibilities are endless for this treat. Place the pan containing the fudge into the fridge and check it every once in a while to ensure that it is cooling off. After it has cooled enough for you to be able to touch it without feeling heat or getting burnt, slice the fudge into small pieces for serving. Enjoy your snack! Finished. Finished.
